importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the military coup and swearing-in of Col. Michael Randrianirina as president, marking a pivotal shift in Madagascar’s political leadership.
The date when Col. Michael Randrianirina announced the armed forces would take power, preceding the actual coup on the 17th.
The date when youth-led protests began in Madagascar, which served as a catalyst for the military coup.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The three-week period of youth-led anti-government protests that evolved into a political crisis and triggered the military takeover.

keyTakeAways: Col. Michael Randrianirina, a commander of an elite army unit, seized power in a military coup and was sworn in as Madagascar’s new president on October 17, 2025.
The coup occurred after three weeks of youth-led protests over water and electricity outages, rising anger over corruption, cost of living, and lack of opportunities.
The ousted President Andry Rajoelina fled into hiding, reportedly on a French military plane, following the military takeover.
The United Nations and African Union condemned the coup as unconstitutional, with the AU suspending Madagascar from the organization.
Randrianirina, previously imprisoned for an attempted mutiny, claims he took power to 'take responsibility as citizens and patriots' to save a 'dying country'.
He announced that Madagascar will be governed by a military council under his leadership for 18 months to two years before any new elections, delaying democratic transitions.
The military takeover has sparked global concern about the erosion of democratic norms and the potential for military intervention in civilian governance.
The coup is seen as possibly exploiting the youth uprising, raising questions about whether the military capitalized on public frustration to seize power.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A sovereign nation in the Indian Ocean off East Africa, known for its unique biodiversity and political instability.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The country is central to the article as the setting for a military coup and political upheaval following youth protests and a failed democratic transition.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An army colonel and commander of the CAPSAT unit who led the military coup and was sworn in as president.

namedEntities.name: Andry Rajoelina
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former president of Madagascar, ousted by the military coup and now in hiding.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His removal from office marks a key political shift, and his absence underscores the legitimacy crisis following the coup.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A judicial body that held the swearing-in ceremony for the new president.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was the venue where the military leader was formally sworn in, suggesting a constitutional mechanism was used to legitimize the takeover, though controversially.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a lightning-fast military coup on October 17, 2025, Madagascar’s army colonel Michael Randrianirina seized power by taking control of the High Constitutional Court, where he was sworn in as president. The move followed three weeks of youth-led protests over water and electricity shortages, corruption, and lack of opportunity, which had led to at least 22 deaths. Randrianirina, a former prisoner of an attempted mutiny, claimed the takeover was necessary to save the nation and promised military rule for 18 to 24 months before elections. The ousted President Andry Rajoelina fled into hiding, reportedly on a French military plane. The United Nations and African Union condemned the coup as unconstitutional, with the AU suspending Madagascar. Analysts question whether the military exploited the youth uprising to gain power, and there is growing international concern over the erosion of democratic norms in the country.
title: Madagascar Military Coup: Colonel Randrianirina Sworn In as President After Youth Protests
